Comments_List: I learned how to think critically about Islamic Art and how to evaluate it from a non-Western standpoint.
I learned how to do independent research on a topic of my choice, and how to present this research in a clear way to my peers.
This course was a great introduction to intermediality in Islamic Art--it also taught me to think critically about what really is meant by the terms "Islamic Art" and "classical tradition."

I wish we had focused more on particular works, maybe reading about them in advance so we could all come to class to discuss them. It felt like there were a lot of works to study and none got very much attention.

The biggest strength is Professor Rizvi--she is kind, but she is also very precise and very thorough. She also did a great job moderating exchanges between undergrads, grads, and the other people in our class, which was not an easy task.

I would recommend this course to students who want to learn more about Islamic art and poetry. The class discussions were very illuminating and the final paper was a fun task which taught me how to look critically at historical works.
I definitely recommend it. It was interesting and fun, and there were students coming from a variety of fields.

Absolutely! I did not have much of a background in art history before this course, which made it scary to discuss the material with HSAR pHD students, but it turned out great and I don't regret my choice!
